name: Joan Jonas: Moving off the Land II (Excerpts)
description: An exhibition featuring eleven untitled drawings by alumna Joan Jonas '65, exploring multimedia art and the world's oceans. The works are excerpts from Jonas's titular installation, continuing her pathbreaking career.

name: Patricia Hurl: Irish Gothic
description: "_Irish Gothic_" is a major retrospective of Patricia Hurl's paintings spanning 40 years, focusing on the experiences of Irish women and themes of loss, pain, and strength. This building-wide exhibition is part of a six-year partnership with the Irish Museum of Modern Art.

name: New York‚Äôs Lighthouses
description: This exhibition celebrates New York‚Äôs historic lighthouses, recognized for their architectural charm, symbolic power, and breathtaking settings. Through expressive paintings and evocative photography, the exhibition captures the lighthouses‚Äô enduring presence and their deep connection to the region‚Äôs maritime heritage.

name: Guided Tours
description: Led by expert historical interpreters, the doors of the past open to you in a walking tour like none other in New York City. See the restored interiors of buildings chronicling eras of Staten Island's past, furnished with reproductions and artifacts in the Historic Richmond Town Collection.

name: About a Living Culture
description: Nepalese artist IMAGINE presents a temporary public art installation inspired by the diverse Himalayan cultures of Jackson Heights, Queens. The sculpture, an arch made of repeating 'Ka' letters, invites New Yorkers into a space of reflection and belonging. This is a collaboration with NYC DOT Art.

name: English Country Dance*
description: Learn the art and fun of classic social English dancing from the 18th century. No experience necessary, just bring your dancing shoes. This program is offered on the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of the month.

name: Chiharu Shiota: Two Home Countries
description: This exhibition is the first New York solo museum exhibition of the Berlin-based contemporary artist Chiharu Shiota, showcasing her intricate installations.

name: Richard Serra
description: The US exhibition debut of Richard Serra‚Äôs large-scale sculpture _Running Arcs (For John Cage)_ (1992). This marks the work's first public display in over thirty years.

name: Senior Cinema

name: Blanka Amezkua‚ÄîPower Flower: Curative Flora
description: An exhibition featuring Blanka Amezkua's "Power Flower: Curative Flora." Explore the artist's unique perspective on plants and their healing properties.

name: Ragtime

name: Lenfest Kids
description: A series of family-friendly movie screenings featuring films by School of the Arts alumni, including "Frozen," "Encanto," "The Outsiders," "Hook," and "Klaus." This event is part of the School of the Arts' 60th-anniversary celebration.

name: Next Wave 2025
description: BAM‚Äôs signature Next Wave offers a panoramic view of contemporary innovation in dance, music, performance art, theater, visual art, and more, bringing iconic and emerging artists together with curious audiences.

name: Standing Slightly Outside: Franklin Furnace, 1976‚Äî2026

name: SUE: The T. rex Experience

name: Japanese for Teens: Hobbies Around the City (Speaking & Listening)
description: This course helps teens develop practical listening and speaking skills in Japanese through conversations about hobbies and city life. It covers essential phrases and vocabulary for everyday interactions.

name: Japanese for Teens: Shopping & Travel (Speaking & Listening)
description: This online course is designed for teens to practice Japanese for shopping and travel scenarios. Participants will learn vocabulary and phrases for everyday situations like asking prices and planning trips.

name: Japanese for Teens: Shopping, Travel, Speaking and Listening
description: This online course aims to improve teens' Japanese language skills in practical contexts like shopping and travel, focusing on speaking and listening. Registration is required.

name: Japanese for Teens: Family, Favorite Things & Me (Speaking & Listening)
description: This online course helps teens practice Japanese for conversations about family, favorite things, and personal introductions. It focuses on essential everyday phrases and vocabulary for building foundational language skills.

name: Free the Land exhibition
description: A group exhibition exploring indigeneity through an African diasporic lens. It reconnects with the natural continuum and contemplates the literal and symbolic impact of complex histories on the contemporary landscape. The exhibition addresses climate injustice and confronts colonialism by reclaiming our embodied relationship with Mother Earth.

name: MFTA Gallery: ‚ÄúManos Que Tejen Luz‚Äù by Magda Love
description: "Manos Que Tejen Luz" is an immersive tapestry installation by MFTA Artist-in-Residence Magda Love. The colossal artwork, created with over 250 volunteers, depicts an Edenic landscape and invites viewers into a collaborative artwork within an ecosystem of care. The installation spans the entire MFTA Gallery space, taking viewers on a journey from night into dawn.
short_name: ‚ÄúManos Que Tejen Luz‚Äù by Magda Love

name: Whose America? Exhibition

It reflects on the emotional, social, and political intersections of these disciplines, addressing themes such as urban memory and cultural identity.

name: ‚ÄúLet Freedom Bring‚Äù ‚Äî A Collaborative Exhibition Between Powerhouse Arts & AANYAA
description: Artistic freedom must be championed at all costs in our ever-shifting sociopolitical reality. The notion of freedom is fundamental to the American condition, and has always been a heavily loaded concept vis-√†-vis freedom of speech, freedom of religion and other founding principals. On the eve of this nation‚Äôs 250th birthday, this exhibition examines works that exemplify, question or critique freedom in all of its many forms.

name: Free Online Member Event ¬∑ Joanna‚Äôs Psychopomp Salon: The Anatomical Venus
description: The Psychopomp Salon is a thematic presentation/meetup that will explore‚Äîvia images, words, and group discussion‚Äîareas of our founder Joanna Ebenstein's research and travels. This month, we will take a deep dive into the Anatomical Venus. a preternaturally beautiful life-sized, dissectible wax woman created in 18th century Florence, Italy to seduce a general public into the science of human anatomy. Ebenstein will share never before shown outtakes from her travels and work on [her book](https://www.morbidanatomy.org/books/p/the-anatomical-venus-book-signed-by-author-joanna-ebenstein-43rc7) exploring these fascinating figures as we attempt to unravel their complicated‚Äîyet not contradictory‚Äî mixture of of eroticism, the ecstatic, aesthetics, metaphysics, and and the scientific.

We can keep them close through veneration, in which we tell their stories, listen to their favorite songs, or create art in their honor. We can also create memorial dioramas‚Äîsmall altars or shrines to memorialize our beloveds and their lives, so that they can be gone but not forgotten. In this daylong workshop, we will‚Äîwith guidance and support from death doula Lauren Seeley‚Äîcreate our own memorial dioramas for a dead loved one. We will also learn about the importance of memorializing, honoring those who have gone, and creating in our grief, as well as the history of altars, shrines, and preservation both in public and private spaces.
short_name: In Person Workshop ¬∑ Memorial Diorama Workshop

name: Free Online Talk ¬∑ The Insect Epiphany: How Our Six-Legged Allies Shape Human Culture with Professor of Entomology and Animal Behavior and Entomo-Artist Barrett Klein
description: Insects surround us. They fuel life on Earth through their roles as pollinators, decomposers, predators, and prey, but rarely do we consider the outsize influence they have had on our culture and civilization. Their anatomy and habits inform how we live, work, create art, and innovate. Our world would look very different without insects, not just because they are crucial to our ecosystems, but because they have shaped and inspired so many aspects of what makes us human. IIn this image-filled presentation by entomologist Barrett Klein, we will explore the overt and hidden ways in which our insect neighbors augment and shape our lives.
short_name: How Our Six-Legged Allies Shape Human Culture

description: _Beyond: A Living Person‚Äôs Guide to the Dead_ by Morbid Anatomy Medium in Residence Tiffany Hopkins is the culmination of seven years exploring the mysterious, culturally ambivalent practice of mediumship. Drawing on her own journey, which began after inheriting a cottage in Lily Dale‚Äîthe world-famous Spiritualist community‚ÄîHopkins blends personal experience with practical guidance for connecting with the dead. The book offers both intellectual foundations and heart-centered tools, inviting readers to explore the liminal space between life and death. Today, join author and Morbid Anatomy Medium in Residence Tiffany Hopkins for a discussion of the book.

name: Morbid Anatomy Movie Night ¬∑ ‚ÄúBowery at Midnight‚Äù with Bela Lugosi (1942)
description: Join our founder Joanna Ebenstein for a special viewing of _Bowery at Midnight_ with Bela Lugosi (1942), a cult classic crime-horror film starring Bela Lugosi that blends elements of suspense, horror, and noir. Lugosi stars as Dr. Karl Wagner (also known as Professor Brenner), a respected psychology professor by day who operates a Bowery soup kitchen by night. Wagner also leads a criminal gang, using the kitchen to recruit desperate men for robberies and then disposing of them once they‚Äôve served their purpose. The film‚Äôs horror twist comes as Wagner‚Äôs accomplice (an unhinged doctor) revives these murdered henchmen as zombie-like minions, culminating in a tense and macabre finale.

name: Free Online Event ¬∑ Winter Solstice Ritual with Selena Madden, PhD, Begins December 21
description: Winter Solstice, around December 21 in the Northern Hemisphere, is the shortest day of the year ‚Äî the moment when the sun‚Äôs daily arc in the sky is at its lowest. After the solstice, the daylight begins to increase. Because it‚Äôs the deepest point of night, many traditions view the Winter Solstice as a time of stillness, introspection, gestation, and mystery. It is also a turning point ‚Äî the sun‚Äôs ‚Äúrebirth‚Äù after the longest, darkest night. Join mythologist and ritualist Dr. Selena Madden for this free, communal ritual ‚Äî which will involve writing, releasing, candle-lighting, and mythic invocation ‚Äîto celebrate this special day.
short_name: Free Online Event ¬∑ Winter Solstice Ritual

name: Free Online Event ¬∑ Winter Solstice Ritual with Selena Madden, PhD on December 21
description: Winter Solstice is a time of stillness, introspection, gestation, and mystery, and a turning point ‚Äì the sun‚Äôs ‚Äúrebirth‚Äù after the longest, darkest night. Our ritual will include simple symbolic actions ‚Äî writing, releasing, candle-lighting, and mythic invocation ‚Äî accessible to both seasoned practitioners and those new to ritual work.

description: The Gothic is all around us. Isolated mansions, trauma-ridden specters, macabre love, and entrapped women are pervasive archetypes that tune into our hidden fears, cultural anxieties, and forbidden desires. Though primarily associated with fiction, literature, and film, these archetypes also appear in "true" stories in American ghost lore. _America‚Äôs Most Gothic: Haunted History Stranger Than Fiction_ by Leanna Renee Hieber and Andrea Janes is a tour through the uncanny tales of real people and settings that exude that elusive Gothic vibe. Dim the lights, curl up with a mug of something warming, and discover the history that truly is stranger than fiction in this illustrated talk that's perfect for a dark winter evening.

This talk will focus on body snatching in earlier centuries as well as what the speaker calls modernized body snatching in the United States. Participants will be challenged to address the central question: After all this time, why haven‚Äôt we found a way to ensure our own dignity after death?

name: Free Online Talk ¬∑ The Spiritual in Art: Hilma af Klint with Host of Creative Codex MJDorian
description: In January 1906, a Swedish artist named Hilma af Klint began to receive requests from spirits during s√©ances to create a series of paintings which would depict the spiritual plane. These spirits‚Äînamed Amaliel, Gregor, and Ananda‚Äîwere conveying messages to her from the ‚ÄòHigh Ones‚Äô. Af Klint wrote in her notebooks ‚ÄúI am so small, I am so insignificant but the force that flows through me is so powerful that I must go forward.‚Äù And in another passage: ‚ÄúThe experiments I have undertaken‚Ä¶will astound humanity.‚Äù Hilma saw this series of paintings as the most important work of her life. But the nonrepresentational and abstract style of the works was decades ahead of its time. What is the spiritual message of Hilma‚Äôs Paintings for the Temple series? And how do we understand the intersection between spirituality and art? That is the ambitious purpose of this presentation.

name: Free Online Talk ¬∑ The Sexual Politics of Body Horror with Aurora Linnea, Author of Man Against Being: Body Horror and the Death of Life
description: The fear of our bodies as mutating, monstrous death traps is a cultural obsession with a lineage stretching back far further than Cronenberg. Plato called the body a tomb and a prison, Medieval Christians likened it to a sack of worms; while the Buddha is said to have urged his followers to scorn it as a diseased mass of wounds. Simultaneously, women have been categorized as the corporeal class, more fleshly ‚Äì and more _deathly_ ‚Äì than the male. Why has the horrific body been women's burden to bear, and how has the charge of female bodiliness been used to justify social inequality, exploitation, and violence? This talk will offer a radical feminist dissection of the body horror that plagues manmade culture, of men's immortal dreams of disincarnation and their bloodyminded nightmares of carnal womanhood.
short_name: Body Horror and the Death of Life

name: Free Online Talk ¬∑ Glitter, Guts & Glam: The Creatures of the Night with Le Pustra
description: The alter ego is a gateway to the glittering, rebellious world of underground nightlife, where drag artists, club kids, and cabaret misfits transform the ordinary into the extraordinary. This tradition of radical self-invention‚Äîseen in icons like Klaus Nomi, Divine, and the Club Kids‚Äîcelebrates the bizarre and the beautiful, turning nightlife into a stage for personal and artistic liberation. With wild costumes, bold personas, and a spirit of defiance, these scenes invite us to break free from convention and embrace our most creative selves. Join artist Le Pustra for a lively discussion on the transformative power of alter egos in nightlife and cabaret, and hear about his own evolution from outsider to living work of art.

Join art historian Brenda Edgar for a lavishly illustrated talk exploring how painters and sculptors visualized divine judgment, celestial glory, and demonic chaos.
